DOC.brief_summary: This study aims to determine whether abnormal bodily rhythms contribute to elevate the risk of diabetes, independently of the amount of sleep loss.
DOC.brief_title: Extended Work Schedules, Sleep Loss and Health
DOC.criteria: normal healthy men and women between the ages of 21 years and 39 years (inclusive) with normal weight (i.e., body mass index under 28 kg/m2 in men, 27 kg/m2 in women) normal findings on clinical examination, normal results on routine laboratory tests, normal EKG, normal glucose tolerance test, negative pregnancy test for women no personal history of psychiatric or endocrine illness no personal history of sleep disorder, usual total sleep time of at least 7 hours only female volunteers with normal ovulatory cycles will be included subjects with irregular life habits (shiftworkers and subjects having traveled across time zones less than one month prior to the beginning of the baseline study) subjects taking any medication (including hormonal contraceptive therapy), and smokers are excluded subjects with significant sleep apnea (apnea index above 10) or significant arousalassociated periodic leg movements are excluded
DOC.keyword: Affects of shift work and sleep loss on health
